Fig. 2 29Si CPMAS NMR spectra of the bare and functionalized silica support (a) and Au/SiO2–SH (b) samples. Fig. 3 XRD patterns of the Au/SiO2–SH catalyst after different thermal treatments. Fig. 4 Bright field images for Au/SiO2–SH (a), Au/SiO2–SH–H2 (b), Au/SiO2–SH–air (c), and Au/SiO2–SH–air–H2 (d). A bimodal particle size distribution is visible for the thermally treated samples. Histograms showing the size distribution of the small gold nanoparticles on Au/SiO2–SH–H2 (e), Au/SiO2–SH–air (f), and Au/SiO2–SH–air–H2 (g) are also shown. Fig. 5 XPS spectra in the Au(4f) region of Au/SiO2–SH–air (a), Au/SiO2–SH–air–H2 (b), and Au/SiO2–SH–H2 (c). Fig. 6 FTIR spectra of CO adsorbed at −196°C of: Au/SiO2–SH outgassed at 150°C (a), Au/SiO2–SH–air outgassed at 150°C (b), Au/SiO2–SH–air outgassed at 150°C and then H2-treated at 600°C (c), Au/SiO2–SH outgassed at 150°C and then H2-treated at 600°C (d). Fig. 7 Catalytic results for Au/SiO2–SH–air (■), Au/SiO2–SH–H2 (▲ and △) and Au/SiO2–SH–air–H2 (● and ○). Catalyst amount: (a) 0.03g; (b) 0.05g. Gold nanoparticles supported on conventional silica as catalysts for the low-temperature CO oxidation Elisabetta Rombi a ⁎ Maria Giorgia Cutrufello a Roberto Monaci a Carla Cannas a Delia Gazzoli b Barbara Onida c Marco Pavani c Italo Ferino a a Università di Cagliari, Dipartimento di Scienze Chimiche e Geologiche, Complesso Universitario Monserrato, S. S. 554 Bivio Sestu, 09042 Monserrato (CA), Italy Università di Cagliari Dipartimento di Scienze Chimiche e Geologiche Complesso Universitario Monserrato S. S. 554 Bivio Sestu Monserrato (CA) 09042 Italy b Università di Roma “La Sapienza”, Dipartimento di Chimica, Piazzale Aldo Moro 5, 00185 Roma, Italy Università di Roma “La Sapienza” Dipartimento di Chimica Piazzale Aldo Moro 5 Roma 00185 Italy c Politecnico di Torino, Dipartimento di Scienza dei Materiali e Ingegneria Chimica, CR‑INSTM for Materials with Controlled Porosity, Via Duca degli Abruzzi 24, 10129 Torino, Italy Politecnico di Torino Dipartimento di Scienza dei Materiali e Ingegneria Chimica CR‑INSTM for Materials with Controlled Porosity Via Duca degli Abruzzi 24 Torino 10129 Italy ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +39 0706754419; fax: +39 0706754388. Graphical abstract A catalytic system where gold nanoparticles are dispersed on the surface of a conventional mesoporous silica was investigated. The sample (2.25wt% Au) was prepared by functionalizing the silica surface with 3-mercaptopropyltrimethoxysilane, anchoring gold from an HAuCl4 solution and then reducing it with sodium citrate. Prior to the catalytic runs, the Au/SiO2–SH system was submitted to different thermal treatments. The catalyst, either as-made or after each thermal treatment, was characterized by N2 adsorption–desorption at −196°C, CHS elemental analysis, solid state 29Si CPMAS NMR spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction, transmission electron microscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy of CO at −196°C. The bare and functionalized supports were also characterized. Large Au nanoparticles (ca. 30nm) form readily by adding the HAuCl4 solution to the functionalized support and, besides such particles, a second family of small ones originates upon thermal treatment (2–5nm, depending on the temperature and the atmosphere), leading to a bimodal gold particle size distribution. Remarkable CO conversion is obtained when the catalyst is calcined in air at 560°C and subsequently treated in H2/He at 600°C or directly treated in H2/He at 600°C. Based on the treatment-induced modifications in the physico-chemical properties of both the carrier and the supported phase, a reaction mechanism is outlined. Keywords Silica Au nanoparticles CO oxidation Reaction mechanism 1 Introduction CO oxidation at low temperature has been extensively studied on gold nanoparticles supported on several oxides [1–27]. The nature of the support appears to be a critical point in determining the reaction mechanism [28,29]. In the case of reducible (“active”) oxides, a support-assisted mechanism, which involves cooperation between metal and support, is supposed to operate. Such oxides are able to provide reactive oxygen, which is adsorbed in large quantities in a molecular form (probably as a superoxide O2 − ion) and dissociates at the metal-support interface, while carbon monoxide is chemisorbed on metallic gold particles. In this case, catalysts with gold particles up to 12nm in diameter have found to be active [30]. Although numerous research groups considered that gold particles are fully metallic [28], Bond and Thompson [31] proposed a general mechanism involving reaction at the edge of a particle containing both Au0 atoms and Au3+ cations and entailing the support. The crucial role of the simultaneous presence of Au0 and Au n+ species in enhancing catalytic activity was actually reported for gold/ceria [32], gold/titania [33] and gold/iron-oxide [34] catalysts. For non-reducible (“inert”) oxides, such as alumina and silica, little assistance is expected from the support and the reaction is supposed to proceed only on gold metal particles, where CO and O2 are both adsorbed and activated (gold-only mechanism). The main difficulty with this mechanism is related to the activation of the oxygen molecule. O2 activation appears possible on small gold particles (ca. 2nm): in this case, O2 dissociative adsorption can be enhanced, due to either a higher density of reactive defective sites or to a gradual change in the electronic structure of gold while decreasing size [30,35]. In the case of Au/Al2O3 catalysts, a more subtle mechanism, thought to occur only on a gold particle, has been proposed [36,37], involving an Au+ cation carrying an OH− group. The active site is comprised of an Au+–OH− ensemble located at the edge of the particle together with Au0 atoms. At variance with the case of alumina-supported catalysts, cationic gold has been reported to have a negative effect on the catalytic activity of silica-supported gold [38,39], metallic gold being considered as the active species [29,40]. Investigation on the role of the Au particle size on the reaction mechanism is complicated by the difficulty of obtaining a high metal dispersion on the SiO2 surface. Owing to the low affinity of gold for SiO2, conventional deposition methods lead to Au nanoparticles significantly above the critical range (about 20nm) [5]. In order to deposit gold on mesostructured silicas (e.g. MCM-41, SBA-15) with high dispersion, synthesis methods based on the functionalization of the SiO2 surface either with amino or mercapto groups are currently used [12,15,41–47]. By using Au/Al–SBA-15 catalysts prepared by first functionalizing the Al–SBA-15 surface and then depositing the metal, Chiang et al. [15] have for the first time proposed that silica does not necessarily behave as an inert support, provided that a particular activation procedure is applied prior to reaction. The activation step would cause the formation of defective E′ centres on which reactive O2 − surface species would form. Strong evidence supporting this view has been obtained by the present authors on a series of thoroughly characterized Au/SBA-15 catalysts prepared through functionalization techniques and submitted to diverse thermal treatments [48–50]. According to Rombi et al. [50], the mechanism for the activation of the inert SBA-15 support involves Au0 →Au+ transformation, with gold metal playing an essential twofold role: it induces the formation of atomic hydrogen by dissociatively adsorbing H2 and triggers the formation of E′ centres by transferring an electron to positively charged silicon species. The behaviour of gold catalysts prepared by supporting the metal on commercial SiO2, a cheap and largely available material in comparison with mesostructured silicas, would be worthy of investigation. So far, to the best of the present authors’ knowledge, only few papers have been published on the use of amino-functionalized commercial silica for the synthesis of nanosized gold-based bimetallic catalysts. Au–Cu and Au–Ag bimetallic systems [51–53] were investigated for CO oxidation both in the absence and in the presence of hydrogen. The main focus of such papers was on the influence of the pretreatment conditions on the synergistic interaction between the two metals, leading to an enhanced activity of the bimetallic systems in comparison to that of the monometallic one. The involvement of the silica support in the reaction mechanism was not fully elucidated. In the present work, mechanistic aspects of the catalytic behaviour of gold supported on commercial silica in the low-temperature CO oxidation have been investigated. Prior to catalytic testing, carried out in a continuous-flow fixed-bed microreactor under atmospheric pressure in the 40–150°C temperature range, the catalyst was submitted to diverse activation procedures and characterized by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES), nitrogen adsorption–desorption at −196°C, elemental analysis (CHS), solid state 29Si CPMAS NMR spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) of CO at −196°C. Both the bare and the functionalized support were characterized as well. It will be shown that the observed differences in the catalytic behaviour stem from modifications in the physico-chemical properties of both the carrier and the supported phase induced by the different activation procedures. A detailed reaction mechanism is outlined. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of materials A solution containing 40cm3 of toluene and a proper amount of 3-mercaptopropyltrimethoxysilane MPTMS (MPTMS/SiO2 =0.03mol/mol) was added to 1g of commercial silica (Devisil, supplied by Aldrich). The suspension was kept under stirring at 70°C for 15h, filtered under vacuum and repeatedly washed with acetone. Finally, the recovered solid (named SiO2–SH) was dried at 80°C overnight. The functionalized support (0.5g) was suspended in 80cm3 of distilled water (1.4μS) and stirred for 30min at 80°C; an HAuCl4 aqueous solution was subsequently added to obtain a Au loading of 3wt%; from the pale-yellow coloured solution a colourless suspension was rapidly obtained, indicating that deposition of gold on the silica surface had successfully occurred. Formation to some extent of relatively large Au nanoparticles was indicated by the appearance of a red–pink colour on the solid [54]. After 30min, 50cm3 of an aqueous solution of sodium citrate (Na citrate/Au=20mol/mol) were poured into the mixture for reducing the remaining gold ions to the metal state. After 20min, the solid was recovered by filtration, washed with distilled water and dried at 120°C for 12h. The resulting sample was named Au/SiO2–SH. Prior to either characterization or reaction, Au/SiO2–SH was thermally treated as follows: (i) calcination in air at 560°C for 6h; heating rate, 2°Cmin−1; flow rate, 15cm3 min−1 (Au/SiO2–SH–air); (ii) treatment in a H2(5vol%)/He mixture at 600°C for 1h; heating rate, 5°Cmin−1; flow rate, 140cm3 min−1 (Au/SiO2–SH–H2); (iii) calcination in air at 560°C and subsequent treatment under H2/He atmosphere at 600°C (Au/SiO2–SH–air–H2). 2.2 Characterization ICP-AES analyses were performed with a Varian Liberty 200 spectrophotometer to determine the Au content. Samples (0.05g) were treated with 12cm3 of a nitric and hydrochloric acid mixture (1:3mol/mol) for 3h at 80°C under stirring to extract the metal from the surface. After complete removal of the acid solution by repeatedly washing with doubly-distilled water and evaporating, the samples were filtered and the liquid was quantitatively recovered and diluted to 250cm3. Textural analysis was carried out on a Sorptomatic 1990 System (Fisons Instruments), by determining the nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms at −196°C, after heating the sample overnight under vacuum up to 150°C (heating rate=1°Cmin−1). The BET equation was used to assess the surface area (S BET) and the pore volume (V p). The pore size distribution was determined by applying the BJH method to the desorption branch of the isotherm. CHS determinations were carried out with a Fisons Instruments EA 1108CHS-O analyzer. High resolution NMR spectra were collected using a Varian UNITY INOVA Spectrometer with a 9.39T wide-bore Oxford magnet. 29Si CPMAS experiments were performed with a probe with 4mm Si3N4 rotors, at a spinning rate of 6 KHz, a recycle time of 4s and a contact time of 4ms. 29Si chemical shifts were referenced to that of tetramethylsilane. Structural evolution of the samples was monitored by XRD using a Seifert diffractometer with a θ–θ Bragg Brentano geometry with Cu-Kα wavelength. The mean dimension of crystallites was obtained by the Scherrer equation [55]. Electron micrographs of the sample powders were obtained on a JEOL 200CX transmission electron microscope operating at 200kV. Finely ground samples were dispersed in n-octane, submitted to an ultrasonic bath and then dropped on carbon-coated copper grids for the observation. Average particle size was obtained by bright field images measuring the average diameter of 300 particles in different parts of the grid. The standard deviation, σ was calculated from the following equation: . σ = { Σ [ n i ( D i − D ) 2 ] N } 1 / 2 XPS spectra were collected by an ESCALAB MkII (VG Scientific) spectrometer operating in FAT mode (50eV pass energy) using Al-Kα radiation (1486.6eV, 12kV/20mA). The pressure inside the analysis chamber was lower than 10−9 Pa. The samples, as fine powders, were manually pressed onto a double-stick carbon adhesive tape attached to the sample holder. The C(1s), O(1s), Si(2p) and Au(4f) regions were acquired and binding energy (BE) values, measured with an accuracy of ±0.2eV, were referenced to Si(2p) at 103.5eV. Data analysis involved smoothing, non-linear Shirley-type background subtraction and curve fitting using mixed Gaussian–Lorentzian functions (Esca Tools 4.2 software, Surface Interface Inc., Mountain View, CA). Changes in the Au(4f) signal shape were analyzed by a curve fitting procedure with doublets endowed with fixed spectroscopic parameters (Au(4f7/2)–Au(4f5/2) spin–orbit separation, 3.6eV and intensity ratio R =1.33) using variable position, full width at half maximum (FWHM) and intensities. FTIR spectra were collected on a Bruker FTIR Equinox 55 equipped with a MCT cryodetector working at 2cm−1 resolution. The interaction with CO was followed at the nominal temperature of −196°C by using liquid nitrogen as a coolant. Prior to FTIR measurements, thin self-supporting wafers were either outgassed at 150°C in dynamic vacuum (residual pressure <10−1 Pa) or outgassed at 150°C and then heated in H2 (2.66×104 Pa) at 600°C (heating rate 1.5°Cmin−1, hold 1h). 2.3 Catalytic tests Catalytic runs were performed in a quartz-glass continuous-flow fixed-bed microreactor at atmospheric pressure, in the temperature range 40–150°C on the thermally treated Au/SiO2–SH catalyst (0.03–0.05g). The CO/O2 mixture (total flow, 55cm3 min−1; 1.5vol% CO, 1.5vol% O2, balance He) was fed to the reactor with gas hourly space velocities (GHSV) of 66,000 or 110,000cm3 h−1 gcat −1. For each reaction temperature, the reactor effluent was analyzed on-line (after 60min on stream to allow the attainment of steady-state conditions) with a GC HP 6890, equipped with a HP Poraplot Q capillary column and a TCD. 3 Results 3.1 Characterization The N2 physisorption isotherms of the bare and functionalized support as well as of Au/SiO2–SH and Au/SiO2–SH–air–H2 are shown in Fig. 1 . All samples exhibit a type IV isotherm with a H1-type hysteresis loop, typical of mesoporous solids with a narrow distribution of the pore size (Fig. 1a–d). This is confirmed by the pore size distribution plots (Fig. 1e–h). The surface area (S BET) and pore volume (V p) values for silica are 300m2 g−1 and 1.14cm3 g−1, whereas those for SiO2–SH are 293m2 g−1 and 1.02cm3 g−1. Upon addition of gold, surface area slightly decreases, while pore volume is almost the same, the S BET and V p values for the as-made sample being 281m2 g−1 and 1.05cm3 g−1, respectively. No significant changes are observed when Au/SiO2–SH is submitted to calcination in air at 560°C and subsequent H2 treatment at 600°C, the resulting Au/SiO2–SH–air–H2 catalyst having a surface area of 285m2 g−1 and a pore volume of 1.07cm3 g−1. The effectiveness of the functionalization procedure was checked by CHS elemental analysis. Both the sulphur and the carbon contents can be considered as representative of the amount of incorporated MPTMS, whereas the hydrogen content can also result from water physically adsorbed on the surface. For the as-prepared SiO2–SH sample, comparison between the nominal C and S amounts (1.84 and 1.56wt%, respectively) and the experimental ones (1.70 and 1.41wt%, respectively) indicates that ca. 90% of the functionalizing agent was incorporated in the silica framework. Despite the high functionalization efficiency and the large concentration of mercaptopropyl groups (SH/Au molar ratio = 3), the loaded gold amount (2.25wt%), determined by ICP-AES analysis, was found lower than the theoretical value (3wt%). Very low carbon content (ca. 0.1wt%) was revealed on the thermally treated samples, whatever the treatment, showing that the mercaptopropyl groups from the silica surface had been successfully removed either by calcination or by H2/He treatment at high temperatures. 29Si CPMAS NMR results are summarized in Fig. 2 . A group of signals is present in the high field region (−80 to −120ppm) for both the bare and the functionalized support (Fig. 2a). They can be attributed to the silicon atoms (Q atoms) formed upon hydrolysis and condensation of the silicon precursor. According to Lippmaa et al. [56], different resonance lines, ascribable to the diverse nature of the originating siloxanes [Qn =(SiO) n Si(OH)4−n , n =2–4] can be identified in the 29Si NMR spectrum: Q 4 at −110ppm, Q 3 at −100ppm and Q 2 at −90ppm. Another group of signals, located in the low-field region (−50 to −75ppm) and ascribed to the presence of the functionalizing agent, is observed for the SiO2–SH sample. These signals are originated by the silicon atoms (T atoms) coming from MPTMS, directly bound to the propylic chains and incorporated as part of the silica wall structure. Their presence demonstrates the successful incorporation of the functional groups into the silica framework. According to the literature [57,58], the different resonance lines can be assigned to T 1 (−49ppm), T 2 (−56ppm) and T 3 (−66ppm) groups [Tn =R–Si(OSi) n (OH)3−n , n =1–3]. Due to differences in the relaxation behaviour, the relative peak intensities in the cross-polarization experiments are not strictly quantifiable; however, assuming that all the T silicon atoms cross-polarize with roughly similar efficiencies, it appears that T 2 groups are the more abundant on the silica surface. The 29Si CPMAS NMR spectra for as-made as well as for thermally treated Au/SiO2–SH samples are shown in Fig. 2b. The signals at low field due to the T silicon atoms are clearly visible in the spectrum of the as-made catalyst. NMR spectra of the sample submitted to thermal treatments at 560°C or above, either under air or hydrogen atmosphere, do not exhibit the low field signals, indicating the complete MPTMS elimination, in agreement with CHS results. The XRD patterns of Au/SiO2–SH, both as-made and after different thermal treatments, are represented in Fig. 3 . The pattern of the as-made sample shows sharp Bragg reflections ascribed to the face-centred cubic phase of metallic gold (PDF card 004–784). The calculated average crystallite size is ca. 30nm. This is in agreement with what observed during preparation, when the sample rapidly became red–pink coloured upon addition of the HAuCl4 solution. According to Link and El-Sayed [59], due to the excitation of surface plasmon vibrations, gold nanoparticles show a strong absorption peak in the visible region of the electromagnetic spectrum (around 515–570nm), whose maximum shows a red shift with increasing particles size. All the thermally treated samples show diffraction patterns with a clear overlapping of the gold sharp diffraction peaks with broad reflections, suggesting a bimodal particle size distribution. A rough estimate of the crystallite size can be obtained by applying the Scherrer equation to the Au (111) reflection after separation of the two contributions by curve fitting procedure. Besides large nanocrystals (40–44nm), all the thermally treated samples show the presence of a family of small nanocrystals (4–4.5nm for Au/SiO2–SH–air and Au/SiO2–SH–air–H2; ca. 3nm for Au/SiO2–SH–H2). TEM results are presented in Fig. 4 . The as-made sample shows the morphology of a conventional mesoporous silica and the formation of a small amount of gold nanoparticles in the 20–50nm size range (Fig. 4a). The presence of small Au particles, already observed by XRD, is confirmed for all the thermally treated samples (Fig. 4b–d). The particle size distributions (calculated on 300 particles from bright field images) are shown in Fig. 4e–g. The average size for Au/SiO2–SH–H2 is 2.7nm (with a standard deviation of 0.5nm), and for Au/SiO2–SH–air is 3.1nm (with a standard deviation of 1.3nm). A wider distribution, centred at 4.5nm with a standard deviation of 1.5nm, is obtained for Au/SiO2–SH–air–H2. The smaller size of the gold nanoparticles of Au/SiO2–SH–H2 in comparison with Au/SiO2–SH–air can be ascribed to a different mode of MPTMS elimination. In the case of the H2-treated sample, MPTMS undergoes decomposition instead of combustion. Residual carbonaceous deposits should be hence present on the surface. Although such residues are released from the surface, which in the end appears completely free from carbon (cf. CHS and NMR results), the process is slow, thus somewhat limiting the growth of the gold particles. XPS results for Au/SiO2–SH thermally treated under different atmospheres are shown in Fig. 5 . The Au(4f7/2) levels are observed in the range 83.8–84.1eV, consistent with the value of pure Au (84.0eV). Compared to the Au(4f) region recorded on Au foil (FWHM=1.8eV, Au(4f7/2)–Au(4f5/2) intensity ratio R =1.33), all the spectra show broader Au(4f) features (FWHM=2.4eV) with higher intensity ratios (R =1.5–1.7). The peak broadening could be attributed to a differential charging effect arising from the insulating nature of the support [60], suggesting the presence of gold species with inhomogeneous cluster size distribution [61] rather than of gold species in a specific oxidized form. The curve fitting of the Au(4f) spectrum of Au/SiO2–SH–air (Fig. 5a) indicates the presence of contributions at 84.6 and at 83.5eV (52 and 48% of the total intensity, respectively) whereas that of Au/SiO2–SH–air–H2 results with components at 84.8 and 83.6eV (35 and 65% of the total intensity, respectively) (Fig. 5b). For Au/SiO2–SH–H2 the Au(4f) region is reproduced by two components at 84.3 and at 83.3eV accounting for 56 and 44% of the total intensity, respectively (Fig. 5c). The observed components are associated with metallic Au species. Positive BE shifts have been reported for small metallic clusters, Auδ+ species, on various supports [62,63] and interpreted as final state effects [64]. The increase in BE indicates a reduced screening of the photoelectron core hole on the final-state electron, due to the small cluster size and poor electron conductance of the substrate [65]. Negative BE shift has been associated to the increase in the cluster size (diameter above 5nm), caused by the decoupling of the Fermi edge of the metal particles from that of the spectrometer [66]. In agreement with XRD and TEM results, XPS analysis indicates that, whatever the thermal treatment, metallic gold particles are present on Au/SiO2–SH with inhomogeneous cluster size distribution, and the fraction of small particles (below 5nm) decreases along the series Au/SiO2–SH–H2 >Au/SiO2–SH–air>Au/SiO2–SH–air–H2. FTIR results are reported in Fig. 6 . All spectra exhibit a band at ca. 2158cm−1, ascribable to carbon monoxide interacting with isolated silanols, and a second one, much less intense, at ca. 2136cm−1, due to aspecifically adsorbed CO [49,50]. Only these two signals are present in the spectrum of the as-prepared sample, no bands indicative of CO adsorption on gold species being observed (Fig. 6a). A weak, ill-defined absorption feature is visible below 2100cm−1 for Au/SiO2–SH–air (Fig. 6b), which may be tentatively ascribed to CO interacting with Au0 sites. After in situ treating Au/SiO2–SH–air under H2 at 600°C, a band at 2170cm−1, ascribable to CO interacting with isolated Au+ species [49,50] is clearly visible at low equilibrium pressures (Fig. 6c). This band is discerned also in the spectrum of the as-made Au/SiO2–SH sample after in situ treatment under H2 at 600°C (Fig. 6d). For all the in situ-treated samples, no bands ascribable to CO–Au0 interactions are observed. 3.2 Catalytic results The as-made sample resulted inactive in the investigated range of temperatures (40–150°C). CO conversion (molCOreacted ×molCOfed −1 ×100) vs. reaction temperature is reported in Fig. 7 for the differently treated Au/SiO2–SH samples. On Au/SiO2–SH–air, CO conversion is extremely low. An appreciable catalytic activity is observed for both Au/SiO2–SH–H2 and Au/SiO2–SH–air–H2. At 40°C and GHSV=110,000cm3 h−1 gcat −1 (Fig. 7a), CO conversion values of ca. 20 and 30mol% are observed, respectively. In both cases, CO conversion increases with reaction temperature, the curve for Au/SiO2–SH–air–H2 lying above that for Au/SiO2–SH–H2. Noteworthy, the curve for the former sample shows a downwards concavity, whereas an inflection point is visible at 60°C in the conversion curve of the latter. The same trends are observed at GHSV=66,000cm3 h−1 gcat −1 (Fig. 7b). 4 Discussion XRD and TEM results for the as-made sample can be interpreted by reasoning that during gold loading on SiO2–SH both the OH and SH surface groups can simultaneously interact with the AuCl4 − species. Spontaneous reduction of aqueous chloroaurate ions by the silanol groups leads to gold nanoparticles formation, as already observed by Mukherjee et al. [54] and Ghosh et al. [42], further reduction by sodium citrate being needed for transforming the Au3+ ions strongly interacting with the SH groups into the metal state. Assuming an initial amount of 4.9OHnm−2 [67], an OH/SH molar ratio equal to 4 can be calculated. Such a high OH concentration in comparison with SH concentration makes the gold reduction uncontrolled which results in the simultaneous presence of large particles besides the small ones. This is in agreement with previous results [54] for gold deposited on a non-functionalized silica, which showed a broad particle size distribution, ranging from 2 to 30nm. The fraction of the Au3+ ions strongly interacting with the SH groups turns out to be dispersed as clusters within the matrix, being hence not visible by either XRD or TEM. Leaching of the weakly bound Au nanocrystals during the washing step [42] is reasonably responsible for the experimentally determined gold loading (2.25 instead of 3wt%). Concerning catalytic activity, the possible involvement of the large Au nanoparticles in the reaction has been checked. Ad hoc runs were carried out on an Au/silica sample (Au=1.8wt%), prepared by depositing gold from a colloidal solution according to the method reported by Grunwaldt et al. [8]: the resulting nanocrystals of ca. 33nm in diameter were completely inactive in the investigated conditions, regardless of the adopted thermal pretreatment. Any contribution of the large Au particles to the activity of the present catalysts can hence be ruled out. Large Au nanocrystals as those present on the as-made Au/SiO2–SH (ca. 30nm), besides being unable to activate oxygen (as required for the establishing of a gold-only mechanism), are also incapable to adsorb CO. Evidence for this is provided by FTIR results, which show that no CO–Au0 interactions take place, reasonably because of the very low concentration of step and corner defective sites (note that even for particles of 10nm, the estimated concentration of such a kind of defects is less than 1% of the total gold [68]). No CO adsorption can occur on the fraction of well-dispersed gold strongly interacting with the mercapto groups of MPTMS. Accordingly, the lack of catalytic activity for Au/SiO2–SH is not unexpected. The absence of Tn signals in the NMR spectrum of Au/SiO2–SH–air, as well as the CHS results, which revealed only traces of carbon, clearly indicate that the treatment in air at 560°C leads to the complete removal of the functionalizing agent by its combustion. Besides the original large gold particles, XRD and TEM reveal on Au/SiO2–SH–air the presence of small-sized Au nanoparticles (also indicated by XPS results). Such particles (ca. 4–5nm) result from the agglomeration of the fraction of gold formerly dispersed (because of strong Au–SH interactions) as clusters in Au/SiO2–SH. As the Au particle size is beyond the critical value required for the establishing of the gold-only mechanism, the observed negligible CO conversion (<1mol%) on Au/SiO2–SH–air is not unexpected. A remarkable conversion (33 and 37mol% at 40°C and GHSV=110,000 and 66,000cm3 h−1 gcat −1, respectively) is obtained for Au/SiO2–SH–air–H2. As a gold-only mechanism would be disfavoured in view of the size of the gold nanoparticles, whose distribution is centred at 5nm, some other mechanism should be operating. The FTIR spectrum of Au/SiO2–SH–air after H2-treatment reveals the presence of Au+ species. At first sight, the lack of detection of CO–Au0 interactions by the FTIR technique is surprising. It should be noted, however, that recording of the FTIR spectrum requires that the thermal treatment be carried out inside the FTIR cell, where 600°C are reached and maintained under vacuum in static conditions. Such conditions are much more severe than those experienced by Au/SiO2–SH prior to the characterization by the other techniques (and the catalytic runs as well) and might lead to the agglomeration of the gold particles. XRD analysis after FTIR experiment actually revealed that only large-sized (ca. 40nm) Au crystals are present (see Fig. S1 in ESI), on which CO adsorption can hardly take place. Concerning Au+ species, they had already been observed on SBA-15 silica-supported gold catalysts thermally treated in hydrogen after calcination [49,50], their formation being assumed to occur simultaneously with that of defective E′ centres on the silica surface. The involved steps are detailed below. Atomic hydrogen, H0, resulting from dissociative H2 adsorption on gold, interacts with a SiOSi group of silica, leading to the formation of positively charged hydrogen species through the following step: (1) H0 + SiOSi → SiOH+ Si +e− The electrons formed in step (1) may interact with the silanol groups of silica [69]: (2) SiOH+e− → SiO− +H0 E′ centres could then form by rupture of a SiO bond of the SiOH+ Si group and subsequent electron transfer from Au0 to positively charged silicon atoms as a result of the following reactions: (3) SiOH+ Si →SiOH+ +Si (4) Au0 + +Si →Au+ + Si Upon exposure to the reactant oxygen, such E′ centres would originate reactive superoxide species, responsible for CO oxidation to CO2: (5) Si +O2 → SiOO (6) SiOO +CO→ SiO +CO2 (7) SiO +CO→ Si +CO2 According to steps (1)–(4), on the hydrogen-treated surface, SiO−, H0, Si, and Au+ species would be present. The exposure to air during the sample manipulation causes the formation of SiOO superoxide radicals, which would evolve into SiOOH by interaction with H0, while the following reactions would simultaneously occur: (8) H0 +Au+ →Au0 +H+ (9) H+ +SiO− →SiOH This would explain why the FTIR technique has been able to reveal the Au+ species, thanks to the in situ treatment procedure. Though a good catalytic activity is also observed over Au/SiO2–SH–H2, the CO conversion values (23 and 26mol% at 40°C and GHSV=110,000 and 66,000cm3 h−1 gcat −1, respectively) are lower than those for Au/SiO2–SH–air–H2 (33 and 37mol% at 40°C and GHSV=110,000 and 66,000cm3 h−1 gcat −1, respectively). Furthermore, whatever the GHSV value, the conversion vs. reaction temperature curve for Au/SiO2–SH–H2 lies below that for Au/SiO2–SH–air–H2, and shows an inflection point at ca. 60°C. This might be tentatively explained by assuming that: (i) besides the silica-assisted mechanism (resulting from the silica activation by H2 treatment), a gold-only mechanism can simultaneously take place, due to the presence of gold crystallites of appropriate size (2nm); (ii) the effectiveness of the gold-only pathway is lower than that of the support-assisted one; (iii) the two mechanisms operate to a variable extent depending on the temperature. The inflection point seems to suggest that an increase in the reaction temperature favours the silica-assisted over the gold-only pathway. According to the above, the presence of very small-sized (ca. 2nm) gold particles does not enhance the activity of the hydrogen-activated catalyst and is even detrimental, due to the establishing of the gold-only mechanism. 5 Conclusions A silica-supported gold catalytic system active in the low-temperature CO oxidation has been obtained by functionalization of a conventional silica, anchoring of Au and reduction of the metal on the silica surface. Gold is only partially well dispersed on the support. A bimodal particle size distribution is observed for the thermally treated samples: large (ca. 40nm) and small (2–5nm, depending on the temperature and the atmosphere of the treatment) Au particles are simultaneously present. Complete elimination of the organic residues coming from MPTMS is required to make active sites available for the reaction. It can be achieved by calcining at 560°C, the resulting catalyst being however inactive because of the large size of the gold particles. Further treatment under H2/He activates the silica support, which makes the catalyst remarkably active because of the establishing of a silica-assisted mechanism. Direct H2/He treatment is also able to completely remove MPTMS while simultaneously limiting particle growth. Worsening of catalytic activity, as that observed for the H2-treated sample, results from the establishing, besides the silica-assisted pathway, of a gold-only mechanism, owing to the presence of very small-sized (ca. 2nm) gold particles. coredata.dc:description: A catalytic system where gold nanoparticles are dispersed on the surface of a conventional mesoporous silica was investigated. The sample (2.25wt% Au) was prepared by functionalizing the silica surface with 3-mercaptopropyltrimethoxysilane, anchoring gold from an HAuCl4 solution and then reducing it with sodium citrate. Prior to the catalytic runs, the Au/SiO2–SH system was submitted to different thermal treatments. The catalyst, either as-made or after each thermal treatment, was characterized by N2 adsorption–desorption at −196°C, CHS elemental analysis, solid state 29Si CPMAS NMR spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction, transmission electron microscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy of CO at −196°C. The bare and functionalized supports were also characterized. Large Au nanoparticles (ca. 30nm) form readily by adding the HAuCl4 solution to the functionalized support and, besides such particles, a second family of small ones originates upon thermal treatment (2–5nm, depending on the temperature and the atmosphere), leading to a bimodal gold particle size distribution. Remarkable CO conversion is obtained when the catalyst is calcined in air at 560°C and subsequently treated in H2/He at 600°C or directly treated in H2/He at 600°C. Based on the treatment-induced modifications in the physico-chemical properties of both the carrier and the supported phase, a reaction mechanism is outlined.
coredata.dc:title: Gold nanoparticles supported on conventional silica as catalysts for the low-temperature CO oxidation
